Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the call button. Every Sunday night, I called my parents, just like I promised. Mom would ask about my week, Dad would tell me about his garden, and I’d feel that familiar warmth of home, even from miles away. But tonight, my boyfriend was waiting in the living room, pizza already ordered, his eyes lighting up when I walked in. We’d barely seen each other all week, and with my work trip starting tomorrow, this was our only chance to really be together. I could hear my mom’s voice in my head, gentle but expectant, “Don’t forget to call, sweetheart.” At the same time, I felt the weight of my boyfriend’s hope for a relaxed, uninterrupted evening. My heart tugged in two directions—toward the comfort of family tradition and the closeness of the person I loved. I sat on the edge of the bed, phone in hand, torn between dialing home and walking out to him, wishing I could be in two places at once.
